taglines: The sound of a normal conversation measures between 40-60 dB SPL
The sound of light leaf rustling measures 10 dB
The sound of jet engine measures between 120-140 dB SPL
Exposure to sound exceeding 91 dB over 2 hours can cause hearing damage
One decibel is one tenth of one bel, named in honor of Alexander Graham Bell
Sound.description:
Sound energy travels in waves and is measured in frequency and amplitude.

The energy in a sound wave can be measured using Decibels. Amplitude measures how forceful the wave is. It is measured in decibels or dBA of sound pressure. 0 dBA is the softest level that a person can hear. Normal speaking voices are around 65 dBA. A rock concert can be about 120 dBA.

Sounds that are 85 dBA or above can permanently damage your ears. The more sound pressure a sound has, the less time it takes to cause damage. For example, a sound at 85 dBA may take as long at 8 hours to cause permanent damage, while a sound at 100 dBA can start damaging hair cells after only 30 minutes of listening.
Sound.label: Noise level

taglines: Aristotle (384–322 BC) first recorded that burning coals produced toxic fumes
Outside of Earth, carbon monoxide is the second-most common molecule in the interstellar medium, after molecular hydrogen.
Carbon monoxide is a temporary atmospheric pollutant in some urban areas, mostly from the exhaust of internal combustion engines, but also from incomplete combustion of various other fuels
CO.description: Carbon Monoxide is a colourless, tasteless, odourless, poisonous gas produced by incomplete combustion of fuel. It is estimated that road transpo is responsible for almost 90% of all carbon monoxide emissions in the UK. Carbon Monoxide affects the transpo of oxygen around the body by the blood. Breathing in low levels can result in headaches, nausea, tiredness and difficulty in thinking clearly.
CO.label: Carbon Monoxide level

taglines: In 2013, a study involving 312,944 people in nine European countries revealed that there was no safe level of particulates, and that for every increase of 10 µg/m3 in PM10, the lung cancer rate rose by 22%
A human hair is around 100 micrometers wide, meaning that 10-40 PM10 particles could fit across a single strand
PM10.description: PM10 is particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter, PM2.5 is particulate matter 2.5 micrometers or less in diameter. PM2.5 is generally described as fine particles. By way of comparison, a human hair is about 100 micrometres, so roughly 40 fine particles could be placed on its width. Sources of particulate matter can be natural or anthropogenic. They have impacts on climate and precipitation that adversely affect human health
PM10.label: Particulate Matter level

taglines: Newcastle typically sees winds from bearings of around 260° carried by the North Atlantic Drift
Wind Direction.description: Wind direction is reported by the direction from which it originates. For example, a northerly wind blows from the north to the south.  Wind direction is measured in degrees clockwise from due north and so a wind coming from the north has a wind direction of 0 degrees; one from the east is 90 degrees; one from the south has a wind direction of 180 degrees. One from the west is 270 degrees or -90 degrees.
Wind Direction.label: Wind direction

taglines: At 30°C a cubic meter of air can contain 28g of water, but at 8°C it can contain only 8g
Humidity.description: Humidity is the amount of water vapor present in the air. Water vapor is the gaseous state of water and is invisible to the human eye. Humidity indicates the likelihood of precipitation, dew, or fog. There are three main measurements of humidity: absolute, relative and specific. Absolute humidity is the water content of air expressed in gram per cubic meter or grams per kilogram. Relative humidity, expressed as a percent, measures the current absolute humidity relative to the maximum (highest point) for that temperature. Specific humidity is the ratio of the mass of water vapor to the total mass of the moist air parcel.
Humidity.label: Humidity level

taglines: It takes 8 minutes and 20 seconds for light to travel between the Sun and Earth
Solar Radiation.description: Solar radiation is radiant energy emitted by the sun, particularly electromagnetic energy. About half of the radiation is in the visible short-wave part of the electromagnetic spectrum. The other half is mostly in the near-infrared part, with some in the ultraviolet part of the spectrum. The portion of this ultraviolet radiation that is not absorbed by the atmosphere produces a suntan or a sunburn on people who have been in sunlight for extended periods of time.
Solar Radiation.label: Solar Radiation

taglines: Ozone pollution tends to be at its worst on hot, still days
O3.description: Ozone at ground level – not to be confused with the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere – is one of the major constituents of photochemical smog. It is formed by the reaction with sunlight (photochemical reaction) of pollutants such as nitrogen oxides (NOx) from vehicle and industry emissions and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted by vehicles, solvents and industry. As a result, the highest levels of ozone pollution occur during periods of sunny weather.
O3.label: Ozone level

taglines: Short-term exposure to concentrations of NO<sub>2</sub> higher than 200&#181g/m<sup>3</sup> can cause inflammation of the airways
The legal limit for the UK's average concentration of NO2 is 40µg/m3 annually
NO2.description: When nitrogen is released during fuel combustion it combines with oxygen to create nitric oxide. (This fu her combines to create nitrogen dioxide - referred to together as oxides of nitrogen NOx.) At typical concentrations, NO is not considered to be hazardous to health, but NOx is central to the formation of fine pa icles and ground level ozone (both of which are associated with adverse health effects). NOx gases also react to form smog and acid rain.
NO2.label: Nitrogen Dioxide level
